method.name: Fuzzy Rule Learning, grammar-based GP algorithm

reference.ref: L. Sánchez, I. Couso. Learning with Imprecise Examples with GA-P Algorithms. Mathware & Soft Computing 5 (1998) 305-319
L. Sánchez, I. Couso. Fuzzy random variables-based modeling with GA-P Algorithms. In R. Yager, B. Bouchon-Menier, L. Zadeh (Eds) Information, Uncertainty and Fusion, Kluwer Editors (2000) 245 - 256.
L. Sánchez, I. Couso. Combining GP operators with SA search to evolve fuzzy rule based classifiers. Information Sciences 136, pg. 175 - 192 (2001)

generalDescription.objective: To obtain regression fuzzy models by means of learning fuzzy rule throught GP algorithms.
generalDescription.howWork:
A GP algorithm is used to learn a fuzzy regrssion model. For each hypothesis, the number of labels and number of rules must be given. In same way, as it is possible to manage any combination of conjuntion and/or disjuntions in the antecedent part of a fuzzy rule, a maximum deep tree size must be given too.
Those parameters are, in conjuntion with GP typical parameters, of capital importance in the evolution of this method.

parameterSpec.param: numlabes: the number of possible fuzzy values for each variable.
numrules: the number of rules for each model.
popsize: the number of individuals in the population, GA-P parameter.
numisland: the number of islands or subpopulations, GAP parameter.
steady: indicates how population evolves. A value of 1 forces a steady, while a value of 0 indicates that new individuals substitute old ones. GP parameter.
numitera: number of iterations to reach the objectives, GP parameter.
toursize: number of individuals selected to tournament selection procedure. GP parameter.
probmuta: indicates the probability that a mutation operation takes place, GP parameter.
amplmuta : the maximum bias that a mutation operation can introduce. GP Parameter.
probmigra: probability that an individual of an island is used in a tournament of another island, GP parameter.
proboptimlocal: indicates the probability to improve GP with local search GP parameter.
numoptimlocal: the number of local search steps, GP parameter.
idoptimlocal: the local search method used, GP parameter.
nichingap: value 1 if niches are going to be used, , GP parameter.
maxindniche: maximum number of individual per niche, , GP parameter.
probintraniche: probability that a genetic operation can take place with individual of different niches, GP parameter.
probcrossga: probability of genetic algorithm (parametric) operations to take place, GP parameter.
probmutaga: probability of genetic algorithm (structural) operations to take place, GP parameter.
maxtreeheight: maximum deep of a fuzzy tree.

method.example:
Problem type: Regression Method: ModelFuzzyGP Dataset: daily-electric-energy Training set: daily-electric-energy-10-1tra.dat Test set: daily-electric-energy-10-1tst.dat Test Show results: StatChekMO Parameters: default parameters but numlabels = 3, numrules = 8, maxtreehight = 6
After the execution of RunKeel.jar we can see into the experiment/results/StatCheckCL/TSTModelFuzzyGP/ folder the regression results for the test set:
TEST RESULTS ============ Model = MSE of all folds: Fold 0 : 0.15308916634036904 Fold 1 : 0.21444503150394698 Fold 2 : 0.19944636130297677 Fold 3 : 0.16464261032298547 Fold 4 : 0.26003322515133603 Fold 5 : 0.15878808162412136 Fold 6 : 0.22035794246237836 Fold 7 : 0.1803217096978929 Fold 8 : 0.251827231966426 Fold 9 : 0.24038710209540676 Global MSE: 0.20433384624678394 Global stdev: 0.037273564083994314 TRAIN RESULTS ============ Model = MSE of all folds: Fold 0 : 0.19375227445599505 Fold 1 : 0.17935429608410036 Fold 2 : 0.17202261620034046 Fold 3 : 0.1970110882061437 Fold 4 : 0.16713204497542378 Fold 5 : 0.14956311691183208 Fold 6 : 0.17454146016677266 Fold 7 : 0.16054293949380663 Fold 8 : 0.20150381554375973 Fold 9 : 0.17609387381997052 Global MSE: 0.17715175258581448 Global stdev: 0.015618788400975525
We can see too the output and target classes for each case of the test set (result0s0.tra) in experiment/results/ModelFuzzyGP/daily-electric-energy/:
@relation daily_average_cost_of_tkwhe_electry_energy_in_spain_in_2003 @attribute hidraul real[27881.8,206035.0] @attribute nucleal real[114760.0,187105.0] @attribute carbon real[33537.0,234833.0] @attribute fuel real[0.0,67986.5] @attribute gas real[0.0,84452.2] @attribute regesp real[5307.0,16357.0] @attribute precio real[0.765853,5.11875] @inputs hidraul,nucleal,carbon,fuel,gas,regesp @outputs precio @data 2.31615 2.40458983095298 2.37613 1.813397827701672 2.25221 2.6475423045770285 2.1057 2.3762580775628397 4.05117 3.5969530972237815 2.50409 2.4749138133991426 4.4184 4.122552283205693 3.07069 3.4607053773078644 1.8168 2.002101411716825 1.1095 2.11571338454915 1.42735 1.8540772499999998 3.34136 4.245246004296703 2.34377 3.0467952862494623 ...
And the test results (result0s0.tst) in folder experiment/results/ModelFuzzyGP/daily-electric-energy/:
@relation daily_average_cost_of_tkwhe_electry_energy_in_spain_in_2003 @attribute hidraul real[27881.8,206035.0] @attribute nucleal real[114760.0,187105.0] @attribute carbon real[33537.0,234833.0] @attribute fuel real[0.0,67986.5] @attribute gas real[0.0,84452.2] @attribute regesp real[5307.0,16357.0] @attribute precio real[0.765853,5.11875] @inputs hidraul,nucleal,carbon,fuel,gas,regesp @outputs precio @data 2.21261 2.763891107741367 3.82169 3.7358698477536643 1.3288 1.8335836962666745 2.53167 2.8129181354468846 4.00095 3.9656458487054933 2.9788 2.8653195993170124 1.67147 1.850189738314518 3.3829 3.150840826272144 3.19877 2.608658293965172 2.4381 2.4989565412390538 0.960987 2.090003800934038 4.14661 4.513092033068567 2.32848 1.85407725 ...
